metadata.sermon_start_end: This Sunday at All Saints is called Outreach Sunday, or Mission Sunday. The word “outreach” is a rather trendy recent addition to the Christian vocabulary. We always used to call it “mission.” A Christian leader earlier in this century said, “The church exists by mission as fire exists by burning.” [...] This is power to move out from ourselves to join our Lord as he takes the part of the unfortunate, beginning with you and me — power to see that reaching out in the name of Christ is the door to heavenly life. And just in case there were to be any doubt about it, we have in today’s Gospel lesson the promise of our risen Lord himself: Truly, truly, I say to you, he who believes in me will also do the works that I do; and greater works than these will he do, because I go to the Father. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific passage. It treats 1 Corinthians 15-16 as a thematic anchor but wanders through Deuteronomy, Acts, and John. It addresses 'mission' as a biblical idea rather than extracting what is unique to the 1 Cor text.
quotes: The principal text this morning is the passage that spans the conclusion of Paul’s Resurrection chapter... and the beginning of chapter 16.
This history undergirds our Old Testament lesson today from the book of Deuteronomy.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Corinthian text or the Deuteronomy text. Do not use both as equal foundations. Identify what 1 Cor 15:58 says that cannot be found in Deuteronomy.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is basic awareness of the 'poor saints in Jerusalem' and the linguistic roots of 'mission/diakonia', but it lacks deep exegetical rigor. The connection between the resurrection and the collection is noted but not theologically unpacked through the Greek context.
quotes: The word mission comes from a Latin root meaning to send.
He is taking up a collection for the 'poor saints in Jerusalem'.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegesis of 'labor in the Lord' (kopos). Why is financial giving specifically the first 'work' mentioned after the resurrection defense? Use the original context of the Corinthian crisis.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest element. It moves from Virginia politics to the Columbine massacre and the Balkan conflict. It is concrete and avoids mere 'general truths' by naming specific societal pathologies.
quotes: Senator Harry Flood Byrd ran the state in those days.
We have all heard about the division that exists in American high schools between the popular young people... and the kids who are variously termed nerds, geeks, and dweebs.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application remains tethered to the text's specific logic rather than becoming a general commentary on the news cycle.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully mixes personal anecdote (the Byrd Machine) with the theological concept of 'unfortunates.' However, the jumps between the various Bible passages disrupt the 'one movement' Dekker desires.
quotes: By reaching out to others, we recapitulate the prior outreach of God to us...
One day, I remember with great vividness, the debate was about the budget.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Reduce the number of biblical 'stops' to allow the hearer to be drawn deeper into the primary text's world without distraction.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The triad is clearly present. Misery is defined as being 'terminally unfortunate' and 'slaves in Egypt.' Redemption is the 'mighty hand' of God. Gratitude is the 'outreach.' It avoids being overly Christocentric by grounding the need in human psychology and history.
quotes: Without the mercy of God, every one of us is terminally unfortunate.
Acts of kindness... are living embodiments of the story of our own redemption.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Sharpen the 'misery' aspect. Being 'unfortunate' sounds slightly softer than the radical 'misery before God' Dekker envisions.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on being 'lost' and 'condemned to death,' but it leans heavily toward temporal loss (societal breakdown) rather than the eternal 'two ways.' The seriousness of the choice is somewhat muffled by the focus on 'outreach' as a splendid concept.
quotes: Remember, we were all justly condemned to death after the fall of Adam.
A person can be lost in time and in eternity.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the consequence of *not* abounding in the work of the Lord. Make the 'narrow way' more than just being kind to 'nerds'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, specifically through the resurrection. The doctrine of the two natures is implied in the 'likeness of sinful flesh.' However, Christ often feels like a 'reason' for outreach rather than the 'life' itself.
quotes: God, sending his Son 'in the likeness of sinful flesh' (Rom. 8:3), made himself one with all of us 'unfortunates.'
Christ is the telos of the sermon.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Focus more on how Christ *is* the life of the believer (Thesis 7) rather than just the example of 'reaching out'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1950 words, the sermon sits right at the 20-minute mark. It risks being too brief for the 'breadth' Miskotte demands, especially given how many different topics and texts it attempts to cover.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Narrow the scope to one text to allow for more 'depth' within the 20-minute timeframe. It is currently broad but occasionally thin.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's ideal primarily by failing the 'one specific passage' rule; it is a thematic speech on 'mission' using multiple biblical supports rather than an exposition of 1 Corinthians 15. While it excels in concrete contemporary application and maintains the background of the three parts (misery, redemption, gratitude), it lacks the exegetical depth required of a minister who 'knows Hebrew and Greek.'
strengths: Concrete application that avoids generalities by naming specific social and political realities.
Effective use of the 'three parts' to frame human experience before God.
Strong connection between the dogma of resurrection and the ethics of financial/social action.
weaknesses: Lack of focus on a single pericope, leading to a 'biblical keyword' approach which Dekker forbids.
Exegetical shallowness; the original context of the Corinthian collection is barely scratched.
The term 'unfortunate' risks trivializing the radical nature of 'misery' (Heidelberg Catechism).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a strong 'speech about the gospel' and 'outreach,' but according to Thesis 1.3, it is not a sermon. It lacks the specificity of a single text and the necessary exegetical depth. It is an adequate address for a 'Mission Sunday,' but a deficient piece of homiletic exposition.
